definition: The hierarchy of everybody's place in society
A complete survey of the land and people in England, made in 1086 by order of William I
A style of castle consisting of a fort on a hill surrounded by a palisade (defensive wall) and ditch
A number of campaigns waged by William I to destroy the previous nobility and inhabitants
A method of Germanic law to settle accusations in the absence of witnesses or a confession by fighting
Money owed by a community if a Norman is murdered.
The main churches of a diocese (church region), with which the bishop is officially associated.
